item.title: Courses
item.description:
Here are the courses I attended during my PhD (in French):

1. Formations scientifiques (Sciences Economiques)

[Introduction à la modélisation : les modèles DSGE]
Enseignant : M. GUILLAUMIN
Date : 15 mai 2018
Nombre d’heures : 12 heures

[Microéconométrie Appliquée]
Enseignant : M. URDANIVIA
Date : 04 mai 2018
Nombre d’heures : 8 heures

[The experimental method in economics]
Enseignant : M. CROSETTO
Date : 23 avril 2018
Nombre d’heures : 8 heures

[Writing in the Sciences]
Enseignante : Mme GAUDEUL
Date : 26 mars 2018
Nombre d’heures : 6 heures

2. Outils numériques et méthodologiques pour la recherche

[Analyser des Données Quantitatives Avec Le Logiciel Stata - Initiation]
Enseignante : Mme FADHUILE
Date : 12 novembre 2018
Nombre d’heures : 12 heures

[Introduction à la Modélisation Statistique Bayésienne]
Enseignant : M. NALBORCZYK, M. PHENIX
Date : 28 mai 2018
Nombre d’heures : 18 heures

3. Formations transversales

[Stock-Flow Consistent (SFC) Modelling]
Enseignant : M. GODIN
Date : 03 juin 2019
Nombre d’heures : 12 heures

4. Stage Label RES (Autrans)

[AUTRANS-18 : Introduction au métier d'enseignant-chercheur]
Date : 12 décembre 2018
Nombre d’heures : 21 heures

5. Pratiques de l’enseignement

[Perform - Atelier]
Date : 9 mai 2019
Nombre d’heures : 4 heures

[Analyse de difficultés pédagogiques]
Date : 31 janvier 2020
Nombre d’heures : 3 heures

6. Summer school

[UNCTAD Summer School]
Date : 9 mai 2019
Date : 3-7 septembre 2018
Lieu : Palais de Nations, Geneva (Suisse)

7. R-in-Grenoble

[1st working session 2018/2019]
Intervenant : F. Privé
Présentation : What can R do for you?
Date : 13 septembre 2018

[2nd working session 2018/2019]
Intervenant : S. Barthelmé
Présentation : Image processing with package {imager}
Date : 18 octobre 2018

[4th working session 2019/2020]
Intervenant : M. Richard, F. Chuffart
Présentation : Organizing a data challenge in R
Date : 30 janvier 2020

item.title: Research
item.description:
Here are my advances related to research during my PhD:

1. Statistical software

[Retrieving data]

Using the packages quandl and BIS, I’ve learned techniques to retrieve data online. The first is used to collect financial markets data, while the second offers a direct connection to the data supplied by the Bank for International Settlements.

Example of code:

library(quantmod)
library(dplyr)

# DATA FROM YAHOO FINANCE
# IBOVESPA (^BVSP)

getSymbols("^BVSP",src="yahoo", from="1900-01-01")
BVSP.DF <- data.frame(Date=index(BVSP),coredata(BVSP))
BVSP.DF <- dplyr::select(BVSP.DF,Date, BVSP.Close)
plot(BVSP.DF)


library(devtools)
library(BIS)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# DATA FROM BIS
# POLICY RATES (INTEREST RATES)

datasets <- get_datasets()
head(datasets, 23)
prates <- get_bis(datasets$url[23], quiet = TRUE)
BRLIR <- subset(prates, ref_area == "BR")
BRLIR <- dplyr::select(BRLIR, date, obs_value)
names(BRLIR)[names(BRLIR) == "obs_value"] <- "BRLIR"
BRLIR <- BRLIR[BRLIR$date >= "2000-01-01" & BRLIR$date <= "2020-02-03",]
BIR <- ggplot(BRLIR, aes(x=date, y=BRLIR)) +
  geom_line() + 
  xlab("")
BIR


[Time series econometrics]

I’ve studied the following topics:

  • Panel data
  • Vector-autogressive models (VAR)
  • Structural Vector-autogressive models (SVAR)
  • Granger-causality
  • Unit-roots testing

[Programming]

I’ve learned to code .do files, like this:

clear all
log using "resultats_`c(current_date)'.log", replace
capture log
set more off
global data "C:\Data\"
cd "$data\"
import excel "C:\Data\CHF.data.xlsx", firstrow
format Obs %tw
tsset Obs

*** Generate new variables

g CT = Short/Long
mvencode CT, mv(0)
g IRD = IR - USIR

*** Generate variables in first differences

gen dER = d.ER

*** Generate variables in log

g lER = log(ER)

*** Data manipulation

drop if Obs==1

*** Group of variables

global levelvar ER CT IRD VIX SM SMUS
global logvar lER lCT IRD lVIX lSM lSMUS

*** Graphics

foreach var of varlist $levelvar {
quietly: line `var' Obs, saving(level`var', replace)
quietly: graph export "`var'-level.pdf", replace
}
quietly: gr combine levelER.gph levelCT.gph levelIRD.gph levelVIX.gph levelSM.gph levelSMUS.gph, saving(level_all, replace)
quietly: graph export "level_all.pdf", replace

*** Generate time dummy, following changes in IR (Switzerland, SNB)

*** PI dummy is equal to one in the period of positive interest rates

gen PI=(Obs<=378)

*** NI dummy is equal to one in the period of negative interest rates (23 December 
*> 2014, onwards).

gen NI=(Obs>=379)

*** QE2 dummy is equal to one to the recent QE in the U.S.

gen QE2=(Obs>=620)

*** Unit root tests

clemao1 ER
putexcel B2=rscalars using results, sheet("CLEMAO") modify
clemao1 CT
putexcel C2=rscalars using results, sheet("CLEMAO") modify

*** Correlation matrix

pwcorr $logvar, sig

*** Histogram graphs

foreach var of varlist $logvar {
quietly: histogram `var', freq normal saving(`var', replace)
quietly: graph export "l`var'.pdf", replace
}

*** Combine graphs

quietly: gr combine lCT.gph lER.gph IRD.gph lVIX.gph lSM.gph lSMUS.gph, saving(histogram_log_all, replace)
quietly: graph export "histogram_log_all.pdf", replace

*** Closing log

save Granger.dta, replace

saveold Granger_stata13.dta, replace

save "$data\Granger.dta", replace

log close


[Time series econometrics]

I’ve also studied the following topics:

  • Panel data
  • Vector-autogressive models (VAR)
  • Structural Vector-autogressive models (SVAR)
  • Granger-causality
  • Unit-roots testing

2. Paper Presentations

[Currency Carry Trade Effects in Developed and Developing Countries:
The cases of Switzerland and Brazil]

Event: Atelier Doctorant - Centre de Recherche en Economie de Grenoble (CREG)
Date: 29 November 2018
Place: Université Grenoble Alpes, Grenoble, France

[Carry trade in developing and developed countries: 
A Granger causality analysis with the Toda-Yamamoto approach]

Event: YSI North America Convening 2019
Date: 22-24 February 2019
Place: University of Southern California Dornsife, Los Angeles, USA

Event: 10ème Journée Doctorale d’Economie (JDE)
Date: 10 April 2019
Place: Université Grenoble Alpes, Grenoble, France
Discussant: Cyriac Guillaumin

Event: 11th Annual PhD Student Conference – Post Keynesian Economics Society
Date: 28 May 2019
Place: Goldsmiths, University of London, Londres, United Kingdom
Discussant: Annina Kaltenbrunner

Event: 16th International Conference Developments in Economic Theory and Policy
Date: 27-28 June 2019
Place: University of the Basque Country, Bilbao, Spain

Event: 23rd Forum for Macroeconomics and Macroeconomic Policies (FMM)
Date: 24-26 October 2019
Place: Berlin, Germany

[Carry trade and negative interest rates in Switzerland]

Event: 46th Annual Conference - Eastern Economic Association
Date: 27 February - 1 March 2020 (forthcoming)
Place: Boston, USA

3. Publishing Toolkit

rticles / Hugo Academic / xaringan

item.title: Carry trade and negative interest rates in Switzerland
Slides
item.description:
Carry trade and negative interest rates in Switzerland

Bruno Thiago Tomio | Guillaume Vallet

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export : E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation
